text: Hahah so you feel my pain! Cheers Jon, I'll bookmark this for future. Very helpful!
For some modules that are strictly used for settings instead of content, it would be nice to have a settings module section, (that way we don’t have to put it on the design manager layout editor)
Current Design Manger. Settings module (a module designed to change a page’s background settings) clutters layout content modules
Maybe bring modules made strictly for settings into its own section.
using E-commerce bridge api submitted products in the templates, and modules like slider, just like abandoned cart details ( associated deal items )
Hey John, thanks for the feedback. Do you have an example of what kind of settings you’re adding?

sure, for a marketplace template I am providing options for users to change the page’s:
1. background color
2. background image
3. font family (google font options)
4. accent colors
5. default font sizes
6. font colors
7. form style choices (rounded, pill, square, etc)
Gotcha. Very helpful, thanks!
IDEA: A *bulk add choices* option for choice fields in custom modules.
bulk choice example in gravity forms
agreed - a similar ui to what is currently done for contact properties in a form would also work.(for example common things like lists of states and whatnot
yep

sure thing!
Right now I do the trick with JSON & FTP but will be much better if we can handle also from the DM
noice, can you go into details on how you’re doing that with json+ftp, <@U7ADCU3BM>?
He’s talking about if you  create a choice field in HS then use the ftp to access the json file for the module, there’s an array of choices you can edit then upload again to change
ahhhh, got it. You’re the man, <@U7SL518D6>

yup, exactly :slightly_smiling_face:
Basically I use it if I have to copy some fields from one CM to others
IDEA: Previewing an email with smart content blocks without having to send emails as a specific contact that meets the criteria
you’d think that’d be kinda easy to implement. they already have something like that with page previews

on `settings > website > pages > branding` under the logo options…
Can HubSpot add font options for typography elements like in the `settings > marketing > email` section? The idea would generate a global typography stylesheet. Users could have font options from google fonts or typekit. Each element below would have a typography setting like the screen shot
1. body
2. h1
3. h2
4. h3
5. h4
6. h5
7. h6
8. navigation
<@U3T21PDBK> This is what is known as a style sheet.
Not to play down your need.
But those thing should be handled in a styles sheet.
<@U38EZFVFE>, of course. But we could say that about every GUI option - even the email font settings. Some designers (especially typography nuts) want this control with a GUI
hmm. For email i totally get this.
To clarify, the GUI would generate a global font stylesheet. It would enable a designer (not developer) to control basic font selections. Plenty of shopify and wp themes give this ability.
I think that this would be nice for custom template creation. Giving that power to your average marketer though is like handing a grenade to a chimpanzee.

fair enough, I totally think y’all’s reservations are valid. But if you look at the options under `settings > website > pages` the average marketer technically has the power to load jQuery in the footer and change the jQuery version - talk about a chimp handling a grenade! Instead of making bad font choices, they can potentially break site functionality. I argue for centralized font settings in order to help companies stay on brand.

For example, plenty of our clients have had a “dangerous marketer” randomly go and download templates from the marketplace and choose random google fonts provided with the template pack. Their pages ended up looking like a ransom note because they had too many fonts. If font options were not provided and they were centralized, that wouldn’t have happened. And the average marketer isn’t going to think to include their company stylesheets when they are downloading templates from the marketplace, but if they do… the company’s stylesheets may break or alter a marketplace template.

What if a marketplace template could prevent this by providing a typography setting called “inherit from global font settings”?

IDK… just an idea. And I definitely understand y’all’s reservations. Sorry for the long post

Hahah! Very true, they pretty much have every other opportunity to screw things up. I guess I don’t really see the situation where this would be used. I’m checkered by my own process where everything is contained in the master CSS for that particular build.

Within custom modules, we have an option to provide a choice field for pages. I'd really like the same thing for blog posts. Currently we can have a picker to select a blog, but not the specific posts of the blog. There is no way to provide a blog post picker that I know of. I'd like a little blog choice field that marketers could use to pull metadata and featured image from said blog post onto a page.
I’m curious, do any of your clients download templates from the marketplace?
It’s pretty rare but yes
We try to get clients who will do the entire build with us so we don’t have to reverse engineer marketplace templates
Also lots of the old templates are dependent on the old design manager which is a nightmare
gotcha! I was gonna ask you about having to reverse engineer the marketplace template haha. Do you globally attach your stylesheets, or do you attach it to each individual template?
Yeah our method is to have an html module that only has the link to the CSS file which is stored locally
Then we include that module in each template
And every time we compile our SCSS it gets pushed to the HubSpot portal

So that way it only appears on templates that we made, so if they’re already on HubSpot or whatever we aren’t stepping on any other styles. Also allows us to get around the caching with that timestamp hack.
cool
